text: I have a price taking strategy that produces good backtest results when backing (ROI 9% over approximately 20000 events) and bad results when laying (ROI -11% over the same events). I'm a bit perplexed why this is - my only theory is that the predictions are in some way biased towards 1 but in such a way that doesn't destroy all value when backing. This doesn't seem very convincing. Anyone experienced anything similar and were you able to resolve it? Any suggestions for where to start working out what's going on?

text: Need finer bet analysis. Depends on what kind of bets / time decay and what odds. Strong trend dynamics and attractor states exist so backing particular outcomes gives you excess value one way and not the other

elements.text: Need finer bet analysis. Depends on what kind of bets / time decay and what odds. Strong trend dynamics and attractor states exist so backing particular outcomes gives you excess value one way and not the other

text: Without any more information, I'd answer similarly to <@U01B8031PM1>. It's not unreasonable, depending on the context. Calibration graphs on both your predictions and on market prices may be useful

elements.text: Without any more information, I'd answer similarly to
. It's not unreasonable, depending on the context. Calibration graphs on both your predictions and on market prices may be useful

text:
Time decay is an interesting shout. I'd push back by saying laying seems to be just terrible regardless of how I break the bets down. For example, here is by expected ROI:

```                             roi
eroi_bin                        
(-0.00099329, 0.00626] -0.063590
(0.00626, 0.0145]      -0.078508
(0.0145, 0.0248]       -0.041157
(0.0248, 0.038]        -0.085013
(0.038, 0.0551]        -0.163211
(0.0551, 0.08]         -0.120441
(0.08, 0.118]          -0.180517
(0.118, 0.185]         -0.259979
(0.185, 0.318]         -0.090304
(0.318, 1.2]           -0.010025```
For time decay or anything else really, I would've thought that you should still see higher margin bets making money even if the lower margin stuff doesn't. Unless you think there is selection bias? i.e. you're more likely to get filled as time decays against you. Doesn't seem to be borne out by breaking down by pickup (getting matched at better price than requested):

```                 roi
has_pickup          
False      -0.116122
True       -0.112633```

text: Has anyone found a good source for each UK greyhounds weight on the day which is released before the race? the major sites seem to release this information either after the race or at the end of the day. I also think on paper it should be an important factor

elements.text: Has anyone found a good source for each UK greyhounds weight on the day which is released before the race? the major sites seem to release this information either after the race or at the end of the day. I also think on paper it should be an important factor

text: Not sure this would be any use unless weights were taken immediately prior to the race - and there is not much chance of getting that. Are you looking to test out the old "feed up the favourite" theory that trackside punters have used since the dawn of time to explain why their bet lost?

elements.text: Not sure this would be any use unless weights were taken immediately prior to the race - and there is not much chance of getting that. Are you looking to test out the old "feed up the favourite" theory that trackside punters have used since the dawn of time to explain why their bet lost?

text: So here's the thing, I'm fairly sure weights are taken before the race, as there are rules that greyhounds can't deviate too much from their previous race weight. I was hoping to find some trends somewhere ... but without the pre race weights theres not much point

elements.text: So here's the thing, I'm fairly sure weights are taken before the race, as there are rules that greyhounds can't deviate too much from their previous race weight. I was hoping to find some trends somewhere ... but without the pre race weights theres not much point

text: They are weighed prior to each race, but I don't believe that the data is available electronically anywhere at that time. Indeed I'm pretty sure that there's a single data pipeline as any mistakes seem to be replicated everywhere.

elements.text: They are weighed prior to each race, but I don't believe that the data is available electronically anywhere at that time. Indeed I'm pretty sure that there's a single data pipeline as any mistakes seem to be replicated everywhere.

text: I believe that at some tracks the weights are written on a board, and therefore available pre-race, but you have to be at the track to see them.

elements.text: I believe that at some tracks the weights are written on a board, and therefore available pre-race, but you have to be at the track to see them.

text:
I should stop being precious and just say this is in-running horses. Not exactly sure what you mean by binary market but it's only betting on WIN so one winner (dead heats aside)

In the backtest I place one bet per selection per side to avoid any double counting of liquidity. Across the 20,000 or so events there's about 23,000 backs filled and 20,000 lays filled
